bibl.title: Accessories from the Christian Cemetery of El Deir, in the Egyptian Oasis of Khargeh, Western Desert.
bibl.note: Part of a group of five cemeteries excavated under the supervision of Professor Françoise Dunand. The Christian cemetery is dated to around the late 4th century AD. - 1. Introduction. - 2. Description of the El Deir textiles and their archaeological context. - 3. Common features shared by the El Deir textiles referred to as headscarves. - 4. How to define the El Deir textile items. - 5. Iconographic references to headscarves. - 6. Excavated textiles which have been studied and bear close similarities to the scarves. - 7. Would a better knowledge of life in the oasis in Late Antiquity enable us to identify the El Deir headscarves more accurately? - 8. Historical and geographical context. - 9. Conclusions.

bibl.title: assisted by Elisabeth Ehler, Dress Accessories of the 1st Millennium AD from Egypt. Proceedings of the 6th Conference of the Research Group 'Textiles from the Nile Valley', Antwerp, 2-3 October 2009.

bibl.seg: Letellier-Willemin Fleur, Accessories from the Christian Cemetery of El Deir, in the Egyptian Oasis of Khargeh, Western Desert.

Antoine De Moor and Cäcilia Fluck (Edd.), assisted by Elisabeth Ehler, Dress Accessories of the 1st Millennium AD from Egypt. Proceedings of the 6th Conference of the Research Group 'Textiles from the Nile Valley', Antwerp, 2-3 October 2009 (Tielt, 2011) pp. 96-109, 15 figg. coul.

Part of a group of five cemeteries excavated under the supervision of Professor Françoise Dunand. The Christian cemetery is dated to around the late 4th century AD. - 1. Introduction. - 2. Description of the El Deir textiles and their archaeological context. - 3. Common features shared by the El Deir textiles referred to as headscarves. - 4. How to define the El Deir textile items. - 5. Iconographic references to headscarves. - 6. Excavated textiles which have been studied and bear close similarities to the scarves. - 7. Would a better knowledge of life in the oasis in Late Antiquity enable us to identify the El Deir headscarves more accurately? - 8. Historical and geographical context. - 9. Conclusions.
